Posts.Content: Hi Mariana. I am fairly new to this site too but the support that you get on here is amazing. I am 72 and also live in Kent but this is a big county so you could be miles away from me.  I am so sorry to hear about your problem and cannot imagine what you must be going through. My heart goes out to you if you are anywhere near Medway Maritime hospital there is a fantastic support group who meet on the 1st Tuesday of the month in the evening and you would be surrounded by ladies who are so welcoming. Please come along if you are in this area and I will see you there although as I am going in for a mastectomy on Thursday I am not sure if I will be going on 4th Dec. I can give you a contact number though. If you are not in this area check out with your Macmillan nurse whether there is a group in your area keep strong Ros x
Posts.Title: living alone with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey oh wow. Thank you so much. How much do you want for them? If you let me know the postage I will send it to you Rosie
Posts.Title: Wigs&hats

Posts.Content: HiSugartc. Have these gone? If not I would be very interested as the wig is or was the same style and colour as my own hair Thank you Rosie x
Posts.Title: Wigs&hats

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey. I have sent a friend request so that I can private message you. I think that’s the way to do it Rosie
Posts.Title: Wigs&hats

Posts.Content: Hi All. I had the same issue. After 2 lumpectomies I had to have a mastectomy and my surgeon told me that lobular cancer which is what I have does not show up on MRI scan. Worrying isn’t it?  I have been told that the cancer has been removed but I am having chemotherapy to make sure followed by Herceptin for a year as I am HER2 positive i cannot do any more so just need to keep my fingers crossed. Apparently I don’t need radiotherapy!  Rosie x
Posts.Title: after mastectomy found more cancer in breast tissue

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs50. I have the opposite as my eyes are really dry and sore but the nurse told me at chemo today to use a bit of Vaseline under the eyes when you go to bed for watering eyes (not sure why she told me that when I have the opposite) Not sure whether that would work but thought I would pass it on Rosie x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi I think that it differs between hospitals but this is my experience. My hospital calls you in for a pre appointment explaining all about chemotherapy. This lasted about 45 minutes and The following day I had my  first appointment where I had my picc line fitted and I think that I had a blood test at this time.Also at this appointment I had my first chemotherapy where they hooked me up to a drip but because of the type of chemo I am having the nurse has to sit with me and put in the chemo by hand into my picc line. This lasts about 45 minutes and I am then able to go home. The hospital has also given me all my appointments until the end of chemo. As I have a picc line fitted I have to go once a week to have it flushed through to prevent any infections. You might not have a picc line fitted but because my veins are not strong enough I had to have one. I was quite happy to have one as it means I don’t have to have cannula put in each visit I hope I have answered your question but as I said hospitals don’t all work the same Good luck and I hope your chemo goes well. Don’t forget to come back and let us know how you get on Rosie x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi MooCoo  I was interested in the leg pain you mentioned. I have had 3 cycles of FEC and I developed hip pain last week which is making it difficult to walk.. it came on suddenly so not sure if it is related to the chemo or not. Did yours come on suddenly and was the pain in your joints? Thanks Rosie x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi MooCoo Thanks for replying.  I forced myself to walk the dog yesterday evening and I think it is slightly better today. Not as intense so maybe it came on due to lack of exercise as I had a week where my energy level was really low so didn’t go out much i will ask at my chemo session on Tuesday Rosie
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: I am not sure if I am typing this in the correct place so please forgive me if I am not replying to you in the right way as I have never joined a discussion group before. Having said that I want to thank all of you who have taken the time to reply to my post. It has certainly given me pros and cons and I think that on balance I won’t go for the implant. I have an appointment to see my Macmillan nurse today so will also talk it over with her. I am 72 with a very active social life and I just want to get this over with although I perhaps am being a bit too simplistic. I understand that if I have the implant my body could reject it and then it will mean further operations. My surgeon seemed so surprised when I said I didn’t want the implant so I changed my mind and said I would go for it but I was in shock as I thought they would have removed all the cancer with the 2 lumpectomies so this news came as a bolt out of the blue. I still have 3 weeks to wait for the op. Apparently the tumour has been removed but I have a lot of pre cancer cells remaining and as I am HER2 positive they need removing. Thank you to you all and good luck with all your battles.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you and I will certainly look at the thread. I had a quick look but at the moment do not understand all the abbreviations but no doubt I will soon become familiar with them all.  My hospital has a support group on Tuesday evening where the Macmillan nurses will also be so I will be attending that. My view is that knowledge is power!   I feel more settled mentally now I have made the decision ( after lying awake for 3 hours last night) and telling the Macmillan nurse who will now arrange with the surgeon for the theatre slot. I just want to get it all sorted now as this has been going on since June when I had the first mammogram. Rosemary
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Wow I only found this site last night and thought I had nothing to lose but was not prepared for all the lovely posts and advice that I have received. I felt so alone with this as I don’t know anybody who has gone through this. My husband is lovely but just says it is my decision so is not really much help bless him. I think he is scared! As I am!  I will certainly keep visiting the site for the support and the humour and the positive outlooks although sometimes it is hard to be positive and I can understand if someone lets their fears get the better of them. We are human after all and the nights are long! i was diagnosed after a mammogram in June. I had no lump or outward sign of cancer but I was one of the forgotten ones who was not called for the final mammogram. Thank goodness I attended when I got the letter as I thought quite wrongly that I did not need to go for any more mammograms.  Again a sincere thank you from the bottom of my heart as I don’t feel quite so alone now and if you do have a meet up please count me in
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: After seeing my Macmillan nurse today who talked me through the alternatives I have decided not to have a reconstruction as it seems to me there are too many things that can go wrong and I quite frankly don’t want to be going through any more operations than I have to. I think I can live without a breast although the scar is not pretty. I really hope that I am making the right decision and I have to phone my nurse tomorrow to confirm my decision as I wanted a night to think about it. I must be the most indecisive person going as I sway between the implant and the prosthesis but the prosthesis is getting the final vote All your comments have helped me to come to this decision. If I was 20 years younger I would have no hesitation in going for an implant but the prosthesis that I was shown looked and felt very real and if something goes wrong with it I can get another one without the need for any further operation. i was also told today that I will need chemo and Herceptin which I did not think I would need so it all just seems overwhelming at the moment. Thank you to everybody for all your kind words and support Rosemary x
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you Lynn. This is really helpful as there are so many abbreviations to get your head around. The reason it has taken so long is that I had to have 2 lumpectomies and there are still cancer cells remaining which has resulted in me needing a mastectomy. In between the lumpectomies I had to wait for the histology reports (2 weeks) and then wait for another theatre slot. I live in the South East of England ( Kent)  and it is so busy here with long waiting lists for anything. However the cancer teams are very good and the Macmillan nurses are excellent and very supportive. Do you have them in Australia?  I am hoping that I will be able to get a theatre slot in the next 2 weeks now I have made my decision not to have a reconstruction  i hope that everything is going well for you and that you are now cancer free. Rosemary
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: I have had two lumpectomies and now I have been told that they have not managed to get all the cancer out and I need a mastectomy. I don’t know whether to have a silicone implant or not bother. Has anybody got any advice or suggestions as to pros and cons. I am over 70 so really don’t need to flash my boobs. My life is more important to me
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your reply. I think I will be able to face the scar but I have an appointment with my Macmillan nurse tomorrow and will talk it through yet again
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Flossie25. Yes you are right I do feel more settled now and just want to get on with it. I have a 9 year old grandson and we are particularly close so I have sat down and gone through what is going to happen and even showed him some images which he just said “looks odd” but is much happier now he knows what is happening. His mother had already told him I had cancer and knowing how children build things up between them I thought the more open I am the happier he will be. He knows I might not feel very well with the treatment and might even lose my hair so he is prepared as this is what will make me better. i might like to message you about the mastectomy when it happens if that would be ok Rosemary
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: I have my date now 22nd November and I am getting more nervous by the day especially as the pre cancer cells which I have scattered about don’t show up on a mammogram or MRI scans so it could be more widespread than at first thought. Although I have decided against reconstruction I still get moments where I wonder what if.......
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Is anyone on Herceptin? I am due to start in May and am quite worried as the side effects sound horrendous and I have been doing well on chemo with minimal side effects. 4th chemo tomorrow then only 2 more Rosie x
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi OKs I know I have arthritis but my hips have always been ok as I was walking 3-5 miles a day but this came on within a couple of days and I thought if it was just the arthritis I would have had twinges prior to this. Maybe it is the chemo so like you I will keep my fingers crossed that it gets better after I finish although going onto Herceptin might make it worse. You would think we have enough to put up with with the cancer wouldn’t you? Still when you think about it I would rather live with a bad hip than be dead with 2 good hips! Rosie x
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Liz. First of all welcome to this site where there is so much information and support.  Thank you for the name of the eye gel which I will try and get from the pharmacist x Rosie x
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Thank you everybody who replied. You have put my mind at rest although I am not looking forward to going through the menopause again. That was all over and done with 20 years ago!! However it doesn’t seem as bad as what I have read Interesting what you say about back pain as I have had a really bad hip for a couple of weeks which came on suddenly and I am attributing it to the chemo so I am hoping that the Herceptin does not make it any worse. Rosie x
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Linda. Do you have the name of that gel for your eyes? I have really bad dry eyes and although I have bought optrex drops they are not very effective.Maybe the gel would work which is worth a try Rosie x
Posts.Title: Side effects on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hello JayJ. I was diagnosed with lobular cancer which is HER 2 positive and following 2 lumpectomies I had to have a mastectomy to get rid of the cancer. I decided not to have a reconstruction after lots of advice on this site and have not regretted it for a minute, it is so easy to just put a prosthesis into your bra and nobody would know the difference.  Buy yourself a good bra and a front fastening one is best. I bought a couple one from M&S and one from Royce lingerie which is the one that I found most comfortable. It os supposed to have healing properties and has no seams which could irritate your scar. If you look at their website and go to post surgey bras you will see it. It has front poppers but the only problem is that they only do it in that awful beige colour. It is a bit more expensive than Marks at £36 but worth it. Anyway to get back to the operation I had no problems. I had a seroma which had to be drained once but it was fine after that and I must say that the wound was nowhere near as painful as I thought it would be.in fact it is still numb now 2 months on.  Just make sure you do the exercises so your arm does not seize up and follow all the instructions they give you. I had my mastectomy in November and I am back to normal now going down the chemo route. I just wish I had had the mastectomy straight away instead of going through 2 lumpectomies first. i was only in hospital overnight and they took the drain out before I left which was probably a bit quick which is why I got the seroma. I am sorry that I cannot help with the DCIS as my cancer is different. I will be going on to Herceptin in March I think. Please keep posting on this site as I don’t think I could have got through all this without all the helpful tips but remember that everyone reacts differently so just get as much info as you can and then make your own mind up. Good luck with your future treatment as you cannot have it easy with your husband with Parkinson’s. My heart goes out to you Rosie x
Posts.Title: I am new here, newly diagnosed with DCIS....
